items.title: League president reported to AFL over 'gender weirdness' alleged comments
items.description: A country football league president has been reported to the AFL Integrity Unit over alleged comments about a club's "grooming and gender weirdness" after it was involved in blocking the club from entering a neighbouring competition.

items.title: Lower crime rates in Alice Springs leave many optimistic, others worried
items.description: After years of negative headlines, crime rates in Alice Springs are showing signs of turning a corner but some locals remain worried the change could be short-lived.

items.title: Japan's sacred 'forbidden island' completely off limits to women
items.description: Boasting thousands of years of history and a World Heritage listing, Okinoshima is Japan's very own treasure island. It's also completely off limits to women.

items.title: Trump says U.S. 'absolutely needs' Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump says he's dropping push for National Guard in Portland ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Sunday reaffirmed his intention to acquire Greenland, telling The Atlantic magazine "we absolutely need Greenland" for national security, describing the island as surrounded by Russian and Chinese ships[1][2]. The renewed pressure on Denmark came just hours after a controversial U.S. military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, sparking fears among European allies that Trump's expansionist rhetoric could extend to the Arctic territory.

The timing amplified diplomatic tensions when Katie Miller, wife of White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller, posted an image of Greenland draped in the American flag on social media late Saturday with a single word: "SOON"[3][4][5]. Denmark's ambassador to the United States, Jesper Moeller Soerensen, responded swiftly, declaring his country expects "full respect for the territorial integrity of the Kingdom of Denmark"[3][4].

items.title: Maduro allies now ruling Venezuela reject US claims they will 'comply'
items.description: The Trump administration insists Venezuela's leaders will now comply with American demands after the extraordinary capture of president Nicolás Maduro — but his allies are resisting US pressure.

items.title: Restoring coral reefs could boost seafood yields 50%

featured_image.name: Coral reefs could feed millions if we stop overfishing them - Earth.com

items.description:
Allowing overfished coral reef populations to recover could boost sustainable seafood yields by nearly 50 percent and help feed millions worldwide, according to research published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences[1][2][3].

Scientists at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama and collaborators analyzed 1,211 reef sites across 23 jurisdictions, finding that depleted fish stocks produce far less food than their sustainable potential[4][5]. The study, led by Jessica Zamborain-Mason of King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, calculated that recovery could generate between 20,000 and 162 million additional sustainable fish servings per country annually—enough to meet recommended seafood intake for up to 1.4 million additional people per year[6][1][5].

"Our study quantifies how much is being lost by having overfished reef fish communities in terms of food provisioning and, in turn, how much could be gained from rebuilding reef fish stocks and managing them at sustainable levels," Zamborain-Mason said[6][1][4].

items.title: China demands US free Maduro after Venezuela raid

featured_image.name: China urges US to 'stop toppling' Venezuelan government ...

items.description:
China has called on the United States to immediately release Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, following a dramatic US military operation that captured and removed them from Venezuela in the early hours of January 3. Beijing condemned the action as a clear violation of international law and urged Washington to stop efforts to topple the Venezuelan government[1][2][3][4].

"China expresses grave concern over the U.S. forcibly seizing President Nicolás Maduro and his wife and taking them out of the country," the Chinese Foreign Ministry said in a statement posted Sunday on its website[5][6][7]. "The U.S.'s move is in clear violation of international law, basic norms in international relations, and the purposes and principles of the UN Charter."

This marks Beijing's second statement since Saturday, when President Donald Trump announced that US forces had captured Maduro and his wife during what officials called Operation Absolute Resolve[8][9]. The military operation involved more than 150 aircraft striking Venezuelan military installations and disabling the country's air defenses before special forces extracted Maduro from Caracas[9][10].

items.title: Were the US actions in Venezuela legal under international law?
items.description: International law is created by all states, not just the powerful few. This makes international community reactions to breaches particularly important.

items.title: The Australian dollar is at a critical crossroads. Which way will it go?
items.description: The value of Australia's currency could move significantly up or down depending on the direction of interest rates. But the global economic backdrop will also be crucial in determining its direction.

items.title: Iran, Russia, China condemn US capture of Maduro

featured_image.name: Russian Foreign Ministry condemns US armed aggression against ...

items.description:
Iran, Russia, China, and a coalition of Latin American nations issued sharp rebukes of the US military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday, fracturing the international community over questions of sovereignty and legal authority. The coordinated denunciations highlighted deep divisions over President Donald Trump's intervention, with even traditional American allies expressing alarm about violations of international law.

Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the operation as "a clear instance of state terrorism" during a phone call with Venezuelan Foreign Minister Yvan Gil Pinto on Saturday[1][2][3][4]. Iran's Foreign Ministry called the action "a flagrant violation" of Venezuela's sovereignty and territorial integrity, urging the United Nations to take immediate action[5][6][7]. The statement emphasized that the US military aggression breached fundamental principles of the UN Charter, particularly Article 2(4) which prohibits the use of force[8][5].

items.title: Iran protests enter second week with 16 dead, 580 arrested

featured_image.name: Demonstrations turn deadly in Iran over rising living costs

items.description:
Nationwide demonstrations over Iran's economic crisis intensified into their second week, with at least 16 people killed and more than 580 arrests reported across the country, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency[1][2]. The protests, which began December 28 among bazaar merchants in Tehran, have spread to over 170 locations across 25 of Iran's 31 provinces as of January 4[1][3].

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei addressed the unrest Saturday, calling protesters' economic concerns "valid" while warning that "rioters must be put in their place"[4][5]. His remarks followed President Trump's Friday statement on Truth Social pledging U.S. support if Iran "violently kills peaceful protesters," declaring Washington was "locked and loaded and ready to go"[6][7]. Iranian officials immediately warned against any U.S. interference, with a senior advisor to Khamenei stating that "the hand that comes to Iran's interior under any pretext will be cut off before it can act"[7].

items.title: Rubio says oil embargo to remain after Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Transcript: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Jan. 4, 2026

items.description:
Elite US special forces seized Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife early Saturday morning in a dramatic operation that has drawn international condemnation and raised questions about Venezuela's political future. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said Sunday that an oil "quarantine" will remain the primary tool to pressure the country's new leadership.

The operation, codenamed "Operation Absolute Resolve," began around 2:01 a.m. local time Saturday when Delta Force commandos raided Maduro's heavily fortified compound in Caracas[1][2][3]. More than 150 aircraft from 20 bases supported the mission, which transported Maduro to New York where he faces drug trafficking charges dating to 2020[2][4][5].

At least 40 people were killed in the strikes, including civilians and military personnel, according to a Venezuelan official who spoke to The New York Times[6][7]. President Trump said several US service members were injured but none were killed[8][6].

items.title: Death toll rises in Iran as anti-government protests spread
items.description: At least 16 people have been killed in a week of demonstrations fuelled by the rising cost of living.

items.title: Live: Trump says Venezuela's acting president must 'do what's right' or pay 'bigger price' than Maduro
items.description: It comes as US Secretary of State Marco Rubio says discussions of Venezuela holding elections following Nicolas Maduro's ouster are "premature", with Washington focused on ensuring Caracas now carries out policy changes.

items.description: Former Australian Test batsman Damien Martyn is awake and talking after being in an induced coma for several days.

items.title: Man found in car boot tied up, stabbed, burnt and beaten
items.description: The ABC understands a member of the public contacted police after hearing screams for help from the boot of a white car parked off Woodville Road in Sydney's west.

items.title: No alien signals found from 3I/ATLAS interstellar object

featured_image.name: Scientists Announce Results After Scanning 3I/ATLAS for Alien Signals

items.description:
The world's most sensitive radio telescope has found no evidence of artificial signals from 3I/ATLAS, the largest interstellar object ever detected, according to results published this week by the Breakthrough Listen program[1][2][3]. Yet the mysterious visitor continues to captivate astronomers with unusual features that challenge conventional understanding of comets.

On December 18, one day before the object's closest approach to Earth, the 100-meter Green Bank Telescope in West Virginia scanned 3I/ATLAS across radio frequencies from 1 to 12 gigahertz[3][4][5]. The search, conducted by a team led by astronomer Ben Jacobson-Bell of the University of California, Berkeley, initially flagged 471,198 potential signals[4][6]. After filtering out interference, nine candidates remained—all of which were traced to human-made radio noise on Earth[2][4].

"No artificial radio emission localized to 3I/ATLAS was detected," the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence Institute confirmed[1][2][7]. The telescope was sensitive enough to detect transmitters as weak as 100 milliwatts, roughly the power of a mobile phone[8][3].

items.title: Ukraine, allies advance $800B economic package at Kyiv talks

featured_image.name: Allied security advisers discuss peace proposals in Ukraine ... - PBS

items.description:
National security advisers from approximately 18 countries convened in Kyiv on Saturday to advance a U.S.-led peace framework for Ukraine, including an $800 billion economic support package designed to sustain the country's recovery and growth over the next decade[1][2][3][4].

The high-level talks, which brought together representatives from Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Poland, and other European nations, as well as NATO and European Union officials, mark a critical step in efforts to end the nearly four-year war[2][5]. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said all documents under discussion, including those on security guarantees, had been shared with the advisers, allowing work to accelerate[3][4].

items.title: Venezuela court orders VP Rodriguez to assume presidential powers

featured_image.name: Maduro's Inner Circle Appears to Survive U.S. Strikes on Venezuela

items.description:
Venezuela's Supreme Court ordered Vice President Delcy Rodriguez to immediately assume all presidential powers in an acting capacity on Saturday, establishing legal continuity for the government one day after U.S. forces captured President Nicolás Maduro in a dramatic overnight raid[1][2][3].

The Constitutional Chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice issued the order on January 3, directing Rodriguez to take charge of the presidency to guarantee "administrative continuity" and the "defense of the nation" following what the court described as Maduro's forced absence[1]. Rodriguez, 56, stepped into the role Saturday afternoon, hours after the U.S. military operation[2][3].

Under Venezuela's constitution, the executive vice president assumes presidential duties when the president becomes temporarily or permanently unavailable to serve[2][3][4]. Articles 233 and 234 outline the succession process, making Rodriguez's assumption of power the legally prescribed course of action[2][3].

items.title: Venezuela oil exports halt amid U.S. blockade, Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Venezuela's oil exports fall sharply after US tanker seizure as only Chevron ships sail - sources, data

items.description:
Venezuela's oil exports have come to a near standstill as tankers avoid the South American nation amid an escalating U.S. naval blockade and the dramatic capture of President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday. The paralysis threatens to further cripple the economy of a country sitting atop the world's largest proven oil reserves.

Following weeks of mounting pressure, including vessel seizures and sanctions, oil shipments from Venezuela have effectively ceased, with only tankers chartered by Chevron continuing operations under special U.S. authorization. More than 11 million barrels of crude remain stranded on vessels in Venezuelan waters, while the country's storage facilities have filled to capacity, forcing state oil company PDVSA to shut in wells across its main production region[1][2][3].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].
